page.title: 03AMPNEY BROOK'S WILDLIFE
page.content: Spraying pesticides, Dutch Elm disease, and intensive farming which made bigger and bigger fields has caused the wildlife to become much scarcer. Roadside verges are not now being sprayed so cowslips, cranesbill and other flowers are returning. Landowners are replanting trees; birds and butterflies are flourishing. The {Ampney Brook} breeds wildlife; willow and sedge warblers, ducks and natterjack toads grow by it. Trout, pike and maybe salmon live in the brook. In summer the brook starts by oozing out of the marshy ground. A few metres downstream it changes to a wide brook. Trout farming in the brook had to be discontinued because of parasites in the water. Great-crested newts breed in the ditch by the cemetry. Copses and woodland are maintained as cover for game birds.
